author: By The Editorial Board
title: Donald Trump and American Justice
description: Donald Trump is enjoying the same guarantees of fairness and due process before the law that he sought to deny to others during his term.
content: The former and possibly future president of the United States is now on trial in Lower Manhattan, the first criminal prosecution of an American elected to the nation’s highest office. Donald Trump, who relentlessly undermined the justice system while in office and since, is enjoying the same protections and guarantees of fairness and due process before the law that he sought to deny to others during his term.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: The Connections Companion No. 311
description: Scroll down to reveal a hint for each category of today’s Connections, or head to the comments for community hints and conversation.
content: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sui-Lee Wee and Ulet Ifansasti
title: What Can ‘Green Islam’ Achieve in the World’s Largest Muslim Country?
description: Clerics in Indonesia are issuing fatwas, retrofitting mosques and imploring congregants to help turn the tide against climate change.
content: The faithful gathered in an imposing modernist building, thousands of men in skullcaps and women in veils sitting shoulder to shoulder. Their leader took to his perch and delivered a stark warning.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sabrina Tavernise, Kim Tingley, Clare Toeniskoetter, Shannon M. Lin, Summer Thomad, Stella Tan, Jessica Cheung, Sydney Harper, Devon Taylor, Dan Powell, Elisheba Ittoop, Marion Lozano and Chris Wood
title: Are ‘Forever Chemicals’ a Forever Problem?
description: The Environmental Protection Agency says “forever chemicals” must be removed from tap water. But they lurk in much more of what we eat, drink and use.
content: The Environmental Protection Agency has begun for the first time to regulate a class of synthetic chemicals known as “forever chemicals” in America’s drinking water.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Blaze Lovell, Eric Sagara and Irene Casado Sanchez
title: Inside the Late-Night Parties Where Hawaii Politicians Raked In Money
description: After the state passed a law barring government contractors from donating to politicians, fund-raising parties showed just how completely the reform effort failed.
content: For the better part of a decade, some of Hawaii’s most powerful people huddled together at late-night parties in a cramped second-floor office where lobbyists and executives seeking government contracts lined up to drop cash and checks into a metal lockbox.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg
title: Netanyahu Says Israel Won’t Be Pressured Over Iran Response
description: Top diplomats from Germany and Britain traveled to Jerusalem to urge Israel not to respond in a way that risked a wider regional conflict.
content: For days, Israel’s closest Western allies have pleaded with the country’s wartime government not to risk igniting a wider war by responding too strongly to Iran’s barrage of missiles and drones last weekend. And on Wednesday, the top diplomats from Germany and Britain delivered that message in person to Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu in Jerusalem.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: sparse
description: This word has appeared in 194 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
content: The word sparse has appeared in 194 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Jan. 26 in “What Do You Call a Galaxy Without Stars?” by Dennis Overbye:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin
title: ‘Bone Valley’ Podcast Subject Is Granted Parole 37 Years After Wife’s Murder
description: Leo Schofield has maintained innocence all along in his wife’s murder in 1987, and another man has since confessed to the killing.
content: For more than three decades, Leo Schofield Jr. maintained his innocence as he served 35 years of a life sentence in the murder of his wife, Michelle Schofield. He has been denied parole four times, even after another man confessed to the killing years ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charles M. Blow
title: The Kamala Harris Moment Has Arrived
description: With the issue of abortion rights, the vice president has hit her stride.
content: One of Kamala Harris’s most memorable moments during the 2020 presidential election cycle was when, during a Democratic primary debate, she sharply criticized Joe Biden for working with segregationists in the Senate in their shared opposition to busing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Susan Neiman
title: Why the World Still Needs Immanuel Kant
description: Unlike in Europe, few in the United States will be celebrating the philosopher’s 300th birthday. But Kant’s writing shows that a free, just and moral life is possible — and that’s relevant everywhere.
content: When I arrived in Berlin in 1982, I was writing a dissertation on Kant’s conception of reason. It was thrilling to learn that the apartment I’d sublet turned out to be located near Kantstrasse, though at the time I wondered in frustration: Why was there no James Street — Henry or William — in the Cambridge, Mass., I’d left behind; no streets honoring Emerson or Eliot? Were Americans as indifferent to culture as snooty Europeans supposed? It didn’t take long before I, too, could walk down Kantstrasse and turn right on Leibniz without a thought.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gail Collins
title: Abortion Is Remaking Our Political Landscape. Why Aren’t Guns?
description: Is it possible for us to get to the same place on gun safety that we’re getting to on abortion — where the people who make the policy feel pressure to be sensible?
content: Why don’t we talk more about guns?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Philip Galanes
title: Should I Be Loyal to My Father or My Dying Uncle?
description: A reader is torn between attending a final dinner with his uncle, who has terminal cancer, and supporting his father, who wasn’t invited because of an old grudge.
content: My father’s brother was going through a rough patch financially, so my father offered him a room in his house. My uncle moved in, but they fought frequently over my uncle’s insistence that my father should be more religious. After months of tension, my father finally asked my uncle to leave, and my uncle stopped speaking to him. Later, he was diagnosed with cancer. My father made many attempts to repair their relationship, but my uncle wanted nothing to do with him. Now, we have learned that my uncle is terminally ill. He has invited the whole family — except for my father — to gather for one last Passover. I am torn: It feels wrong to exclude my father, but it also feels wrong to refuse the wish of a dying man. Thoughts?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth Dias and Kellen Browning
title: Arizona Republicans Splinter Over Repeal of 1864 Abortion Ban
description: The State Senate introduced a bill to repeal a near-total abortion ban dating back to the Civil War, while the House blocked an effort to do so.
content: The two chambers of Arizona’s State Legislature diverged sharply on Wednesday over whether to repeal the state’s 1864 law banning abortion, capping a chaotic day as legislators and activists sparred over the fate of the Civil War-era ban.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Vampire Weekend’s New Album Goes Underground and All Over
description: Digging into “Only God Was Above Us,” an LP that’s both catchy and complex.
content: Vampire Weekend recently released its fifth album, “Only God Was Above Us.” From the band that got started nearly two decades ago at Columbia University but now resides in Los Angeles, it’s an LP that ponders hitting 40, the lessons of history, generational legacies, myths and memories of New York City and Vampire Weekend’s own peculiar status as both an indie-rock success story and an arty pop outlier. It’s also the band’s noisiest album — and perhaps its kindliest.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jim Tankersley and Nicholas Nehamas
title: Biden to Call for Tripling Tariffs on Chinese Steel Products
description: In a speech to union steelworkers in Pittsburgh, the president will announce several new measures meant to raise new barriers against floods of Chinese imports.
content: President Biden on Wednesday will call on his trade representative to more than triple some tariffs on steel and aluminum products from China, as part of a series of moves meant to help cushion American manufacturers from a surge of low-cost imports.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kwame Anthony Appiah
title: My Boyfriend Said He’d Save Our Cat but Not a Stranger if Both Were Drowning
description: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on whether there is inherent value in human life more than any other kind of life.
content: My boyfriend and I were talking about protecting human life, and he said that he doesn’t believe that human life is necessarily worth more than any other kind of life. For example, he said that if one of our cats were drowning next to a human who was a stranger to us (who was also drowning) and he could save just one, he would choose our cat. Is this morally wrong?
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: April 17, 2024
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Wednesday, April 17, 2024.
content: An article on Thursday about “forever chemicals” described incorrectly the molecular structure of PFAS compounds. They have carbon and fluorine atoms, not carbon and fluoride.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robin George Andrews
title: This Lava Tube in Saudi Arabia Has Been a Human Refuge for 7,000 Years
description: Ancient humans left behind numerous archaeological traces in the cavern, and scientists say there may be thousands more like it on the Arabian Peninsula to study.
content: When ancient humans pushed into the Arabian Peninsula, they found a world marked by magma. Swaths of it once erupted from volcanoes, leaving a landscape of craters and frozen lava flows. Many of these seemingly otherworldly volcanic fields are adorned with archaeological remains — from small dwellings to colossal animal-corralling structures called kites — that date back millenniums.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Apoorva Mandavilli
title: Long-Acting Drugs May Revolutionize H.I.V. Prevention and Treatment
description: New regimens in development, including once-weekly pills and semiannual shots, could help control the virus in hard-to-reach populations.
content: A pill taken once a week. A shot administered at home once a month. Even a jab given at a clinic every six months.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Ewing
title: Tesla Seeks to Revive Musk’s $47 Billion Pay Deal After Judge Says No
description: The company’s directors are asking shareholders to again approve the multibillion-dollar compensation plan and to move the company’s registration to Texas, from Delaware.
content: Facing criticism that it is overly beholden to Elon Musk, Tesla’s board of directors said on Wednesday that it would essentially give him everything he wanted, including the biggest pay package in corporate history.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Genevieve Glatsky
title: U.S. Restores Oil Sanctions on Venezuela as Hopes Dim for Free Election
description: The Biden administration had temporarily lifted sanctions after President Nicolás Maduro agreed to make free elections possible. Now Mr. Maduro has put up barriers to a credible vote.
content: When the government of President Nicolás Maduro of Venezuela and his country’s opposition signed an agreement in October to work toward free and fair elections this year, it was seen as a glimmer of hope after years of authoritarian rule and economic free fall.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ross Douthat
title: The Real Path to an American Civil War
description: Not just a deepening of present discontents but a dramatic crash or rupture.
content: This week Donald Trump was put on trial by a liberal prosecutor on what seems like the most nakedly political of the multiple charges that he’s facing. To protest this outrage against their glorious leader, the MAGA faithful gathered outside the New York courthouse in the thousands, ready to storm into the halls of justice … well, perhaps in the hundreds, ready to get in the face of Trump’s legal persecutors … well, no, actually it was a few dozen Trump supporters, waving signs and outnumbered by the gawking press.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tracy Mumford, Nicholas Nehamas, Ian Stewart, Jessica Metzger and James Shield
title: Israel Weighs Response to Iran, and U.S. Speaker Tries to Pass Ukraine Aid
description: Plus, the French Olympic team reveals its outfits.
content: On Today’s Episode:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Grose
title: Most Teachers Know They’re Playing With Fire When They Use Tech in the Classroom
description: But many of them know how not to get burned.
content: A few years ago, when researchers at Boston College and Harvard set out to review all of the existing research on educational apps for kids in preschool through third grade, they were surprised to find that even though there are hundreds of thousands of apps out there that are categorized as educational, there were only 36 studies of educational apps in the databases they searched. “That is not a strong evidence base on which to completely redesign an entire schooling system,” Josh Gilbert, one of the co-authors of the study, told me over the phone.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Sisario
title: Taylor Swift Sells a Rainbow of Vinyl Albums. Fans Keep Buying Them.
description: Artists across pop genres are finding success with colored vinyl and different variants of their releases. For Swifties, the urge to collect them all is strong.
content: When Taylor Swift released nine vinyl editions of her album “Folklore” in 2020, Tylor Hammers, a fan in Florida, took notice. But it wasn’t until “Midnights” two years later that he became a true collector, scouring the internet and retail shops for every variation of her albums he could find — spending about $1,000 in the process — and cataloging the technicolor expanse of Swift’s LP output in an online discography.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg
title: Here’s Where Israel’s Military Offensive in Gaza Stands
description: More than six months after the Hamas-led attacks of Oct. 7, Israel’s campaign to eliminate the armed group in Gaza is pressing ahead.
content: Iran’s attack on Israel has shifted focus from the war in Gaza, but Israeli military operations press on there with the aim of eliminating Hamas, the armed group that controlled the territory before the fighting began.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephanie Saul
title: Who Are the Columbia Professors Mentioned in the House Hearing?
description: Lawmakers grilled officials over comments the faculty members Joseph Andoni Massad, Katherine Franke and Mohamed Abdou made after the Hamas-led attack on Israel.
content: Several Columbia faculty members — Joseph Andoni Massad, Katherine Franke and Mohamed Abdou — were in the spotlight at Wednesday’s hearing before the House Committee on Education and the Workforce.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Varenikova and Marc Santora
title: Russian Missile Attack North of Kyiv Kills at Least 17, Ukraine Says
description: President Volodymyr Zelensky said the death toll might rise and blamed lack of air defenses for the loss of life. Dozens more were reported wounded.
content: At least 17 people were killed and scores more injured when three Russian missiles struck a busy downtown district of Chernihiv, north of Kyiv, just before noon on Wednesday, Ukrainian officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jess Bidgood
title: Is Trump’s Trial Really About ‘Hush Money’?
description: Both the prosecutors and defense are trying to frame it differently.
content: As former President Donald Trump’s first criminal trial begins, there is one battle taking place in a Manhattan courtroom, where he faces 34 felony counts of falsifying business records.But there is another fight taking place in the court of public opinion, which concerns a much more basic question: What should this trial even be called?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla
title: Californians Share Their Pandemic Silver Linings, Four Years After Lockdowns
description: Readers submitted small ways that the pandemic shifted their thinking for the better, or introduced a new joy into their life.
content: As you well know, the pandemic brought so much disruption and tragedy into our lives. Many of us are still grappling with all of the changes it wrought.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sui-Lee Wee
title: Aung San Suu Kyi Moved to Unknown Location From Prison by Myanmar Junta
description: The unexpected relocation was attributed to a heat wave, and came as the military government is facing increasingly emboldened rebel forces.
content: Myanmar’s ousted civilian leader, Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, has been moved by the military junta to an unknown location from a prison in the capital, Naypyidaw, raising questions about her safety.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christine Chitnis
title: Sober Travelers Find Something to Savor in Wine Country
description: Mocktail trails, olive oil tours and elevated dining experiences are among the many ways the renowned wine-producing areas of Sonoma, Mendoza and Tuscany are appealing to sober or sober-curious travelers.
content: Amy Snook knows more about wine than your average traveler. Originally from California, she now lives in the Douro Valley of Portugal, her partner works in the wine industry, and she has visited 47 countries, many of which have celebrated viticulture. But seven years ago, on a trip to Mendoza, a winemaking region in the foothills of Argentina’s Andes Mountains, she opted to abstain from drinking alcohol, a decision she would repeat in future travels.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tyler Hicks
title: Looking for a Fight
description: Our photographer spent four days at a remote Ukrainian trench outpost manned by soldiers who signed up from abroad.
content: The bullet-scarred pickups raced the sunrise along a rough dirt road wending through a dense pine forest. The men inside them — Ukrainian, Brazilian, Colombian, Polish — spoke multiple languages, but few words. It was not a moment for small talk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Juliet Macur and Glenn Thrush
title: Justice Dept. Nears Settlement Over F.B.I.’s Failure to Investigate Larry Nassar
description: The deal, which could be announced in coming weeks, would bring an end to one of the last major cases stemming from a horrific sports scandal.
content: The Justice Department is nearing a $100 million settlement over its initial failure to investigate Lawrence G. Nassar, the former U.S.A. Gymnastics team doctor convicted of sexually abusing girls under his care, according to people familiar with the situation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth Spiers
title: Donald Trump’s Secret Shame About New York City Haunts His Trial
description: For a kid from Queens who never quite conquered Manhattan, this trial is a fitting homecoming.
content: With jury selection underway in Donald Trump’s criminal trial in Lower Manhattan, the former president’s chickens have finally come home to roost. It feels uniquely appropriate that Mr. Trump will have to endure the scrutiny on his old home turf. New York City residents have been subjected to his venality and corruption for much longer than the rest of the country, and we’re familiar with his antics — the threats, the lawsuits, the braggadocio, his general ability to slip through the tiniest crack in the bureaucracy or legal system just fast enough to avoid the consequences of his actions. He rose to fame here, but was never truly accepted by the old money elites he admired. The rich and powerful sometimes invited him to their parties, but behind his back they laughed at his coarse methods and his tacky aesthetic. His inability to succeed in New York in quite the way he wanted to drove much of the damage he did to the country as a whole, and arguably his entire political career.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Cameron and Kellen Browning
title: Kari Lake Urges Supporters to Arm Themselves Ahead of Election
description: “We are going to put on the armor of God,” the Arizona Republican candidate for Senate said to cheering supporters. “And maybe strap on a Glock on the side of us just in case.”
content: Kari Lake, a top ally of Donald J. Trump who is running for a Senate seat in Arizona, called on her supporters on Sunday to arm themselves ahead of an “intense” period leading up to the election, urging them to “strap on a Glock,” referring to a brand of firearm.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Schmall and Dani Blum
title: Sophie Kinsella, ‘Shopaholic’ Author, Says She Has Brain Cancer
description: The author of the best-selling book series said she had been undergoing treatment for glioblastoma, an aggressive brain tumor, after a diagnosis in 2022.
content: Sophie Kinsella, the best-selling English author of the “Shopaholic” book series, revealed on social media on Wednesday that she had been undergoing treatment for an aggressive and often fatal form of brain cancer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth A. Harris
title: Hundreds of Small Presses Just Lost Their Distributor. Now What?
description: A nonprofit that distributed books for many of the country’s small presses has closed, and the fallout could affect the publishing industry in ways both big and small.
content: When LittlePuss Press opened in 2021, it had one completed book that had been published elsewhere and fallen out of print and a plan to focus on trans authors. Fledgling as it was, LittlePuss was able to get its book into stores through a company called Small Press Distribution, and LittlePuss has grown steadily since.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg and Michael Levenson
title: Israeli Response to Iran Attack Seems Inevitable, Despite Allies’ Pleas
description: “We will make our own decisions,” said Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, rebuffing European diplomats’ requests to stand down.
content: European diplomats traveled to Israel on Wednesday to make one more plea for restraint in response to the aerial attack that Iran launched this weekend, but Britain’s foreign secretary acknowledged that an Israeli reprisal seemed inevitable.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Williams
title: Barbara Joans, Anthropologist Who Studied Biker Culture, Dies at 89
description: In her 60s, she hit the open road on a hulking Harley-Davidson and found a new area of academic research: bikers, and in particular, women bikers.
content: Barbara Joans, an iconoclastic anthropologist and feminist who, in her early 60s, became something of a Margaret Mead in black leather, steering her Harley-Davidson deep into a biker culture and producing the 2001 book, “Bike Lust: Harleys, Women, and American Society,” died on March 6 in Santa Cruz, Calif. She was 89.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Farah Stockman
title: Venezuelans Are Suffering, but More Sanctions Won’t Help
description: The Biden administration wants to lift damaging oil sanctions but is caught in a political bind with Venezuela’s dictator.
content: President Nicolás Maduro of Venezuela isn’t even pretending to play fair anymore. In October, he promised to take steps toward holding free elections, including allowing the opposition to pick a candidate in a primary process of its own choosing, with the lifting of some American sanctions as an incentive. But the ink was hardly dry before his government upheld a ban on running for office that had been placed on María Corina Machado, the overwhelming victor of that primary. Then it arrested her allies and campaign staffers, accusing them of an anti-government plot. Some have sought asylum at the embassy of Argentina. The Maduro regime has even refused to register the candidate that Ms. Machado deputized to run in her stead.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Walker
title: Boeing Whistle-Blower Details His Concerns to Congressional Panel
description: Sam Salehpour, an engineer at Boeing for over a decade, testified that the company introduced production shortcuts in an attempt to address bottlenecks.
content: A Boeing engineer who went public last week with safety concerns about the company’s 787 Dreamliner told a Senate panel on Wednesday that he was concerned that shortcuts the company was taking would eventually lead to a crash if they continued unchecked.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Sherman
title: Abe Koogler’s New Play Is an Ode to Intense Culinary Experiences
description: In “Staff Meal,” in previews at Playwrights Horizons, a restaurant becomes a refuge as the world ends.
content: Abe Koogler didn’t grow up going to many restaurants. He was raised on Vashon Island, Wash. — sparse and bucolic with an artsy populace, a few miles southwest of Seattle — in a house without a TV, where meals were mostly eaten at home, his free time spent fashioning handmade puppets onto chopsticks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julian E. Barnes
title: China Could Threaten Critical Infrastructure in a Conflict, N.S.A. Chief Says
description: Gen. Timothy Haugh, who is also the head of the U.S. military’s Cyber Command, said Beijing was “sending a pretty clear signal.”
content: China has been trying to find ways to gain access to critical infrastructure in the United States so that it can threaten those systems in the event of a conflict, the National Security Agency director said on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Grode
title: Video Games Are a Playwright’s Muse, Not Her Hobby
description: In Bekah Brunstetter’s new play “The Game,” women withhold sex from their partners who are obsessed with a Fortnite-like game. Her previous work includes “The Oregon Trail.”
content: The writer Bekah Brunstetter is decidedly not a video game aficionado. Her personality type — “psychotically obsessed with productivity,” as she put it — has sealed off all gaming rabbit holes for the past 25 years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Clark
title: Easy Spring Dishes With Time-Saving Shortcuts
description: Sautéed salmon with tomatoes and leeks, chilaquiles verdes and one-pan orzo with spinach and feta welcome a little kitchen cheating.
content: I confess: I refuse to blanch, peel and seed a tomato, even if the recipe says to. Every cook has a fussiness threshold, and that exceeds mine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gus Powell
title: On the Ground at the Venice Biennale
description: Scenes from the pre-opening at the pivotal art event.
content: The exhibitions have been installed. The artists have arrived. The city of Venice is prepared to welcome throngs of visitors from across the world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. D. Biersdorfer
title: The Basics of Smartphone Backups
description: It doesn’t take a lot of work to keep copies of your phone’s photos, videos and other files stashed securely in case of an emergency.
content: What would you do if you permanently lost all the photos, notes and other files on your phone?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Grace Ashford and Claire Fahy
title: A Cyberattack Could Make N.Y. State’s Late Budget Even Later
description: Days after lawmakers in Albany reached agreement on the framework of a $237 billion state budget, a digital security breach threatened to delay proceedings.
content: First it was an earthquake, then an eclipse. What else could throw a wrench into the works of New York’s budget process?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Ravi Mattu, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: Tesla Sets Up a New Showdown Over Elon Musk’s Pay
description: The electric vehicle maker will ask shareholders to vote again on a multibillion-dollar compensation package that was voided by a judge in January.
content: Nearly three months ago, a Delaware court voided Elon Musk’s multibillion-dollar pay package that Tesla’s board — and most shareholders — had given him in 2018, contending that the process to decide it was “deeply flawed” and that the company didn’t properly disclose it to investors.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zachary Small
title: At Venice Biennale, Israel’s Show Is Halted, but Protests Go On
description: The country’s exhibition was already closed after its artist refused to exhibit her work until there was a cease-fire and hostage deal in Gaza. But that didn’t calm the discontent.
content: The Israel pavilion at the Venice Biennale is closed this year, since its creative team decided not to exhibit work until there was a cease-fire and hostage deal in Gaza, but it was nonetheless the site of a large demonstration on Wednesday that drew more than 100 protesters.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joshua Barone
title: Before She Became Music’s Greatest Teacher, She Wrote an Opera
description: Nadia Boulanger’s “La Ville Morte” was repeatedly thwarted by death and World War I, then nearly lost. Finally, it is having its American premiere.
content: In March 1912, the famous violinist and composer Eugène Ysaÿe visited the home of his fellow musician Raoul Pugno in Paris. At the piano, Pugno played and sang through “La Ville Morte,” an opera he was writing with Nadia Boulanger, a mentee-turned-collaborator 35 years his junior.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peace Adzo Medie
title: Read Your Way Through Accra
description: Bus stations. Traffic stops. Beaches. There’s no telling where you’ll find the next story in Accra, Ghana’s capital. Peace Adzo Medie shares some of her favorites.
content: Accra is rich with stories, some of them only a few words long — Still Hustling; Work Hard and Dream Big; Short Ways Are Dangerous — and written in bold letters on the rear windows of tro tros, the ubiquitous minibuses that ferry residents and visitors around the city. These mantras are meant to represent the people who own the buses. But they also tell of life in Accra, and what it takes to make it in this vibrant city.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Kurutz
title: From a Tiny Island in Maine, He Serves Up Fresh Media Gossip
description: Rusty Foster could never live in New York. But his hit newsletter, Today in Tabs, is an enduring obsession of the city’s media class.
content: In a time when the headlines are dominated by wars and a divisive presidential campaign, the magazine-world rivalry between The Atlantic and The New Yorker doesn’t amount to much.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anemona Hartocollis and Colbi Edmonds
title: What to Know About the Turmoil at Colleges Over the Israel-Hamas War
description: On campus, the debate over free speech and antisemitism has only become more charged.
content: As the Israel-Hamas war has escalated, many universities have been caught in an often vitriolic debate over how to handle pro-Palestinian student protests.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Moens
title: Your Brain Waves Are Up for Sale. A New Law Wants to Change That.
description: In a first, a Colorado law extends privacy rights to the neural data increasingly coveted by technology companies.
content: Consumers have grown accustomed to the prospect that their personal data, such as email addresses, social contacts, browsing history and genetic ancestry, are being collected and often resold by the apps and the digital services they use.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Specia
title: How London Became a ‘Hot Spot’ for Threats Against Iranian Journalists
description: Iranian reporters and broadcasters in Britain have suffered physical attacks, threats and surveillance, a report by Reporters Without Borders said, weeks after a newscaster was stabbed in London.
content: Iranian journalists in London have experienced death threats, intimidation and online abuse. One broadcaster working for BBC Persian, the Persian-language branch of the BBC World Service, which has its headquarters in London, had her car broken into, and her conversations with family members were tapped.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Golembiewski
title: An 11-Year-Old Girl’s Fossil Find Is the Largest Known Ocean Reptile
description: When Ruby Reynolds and her father found a fossil on an English beach, they didn’t know it belonged to an 82-foot ichthyosaur that swam during the days of the dinosaurs.
content: In 1811, a 12-year-old girl named Mary Anning discovered a fossil on the beach near her home in southwestern England — the first scientifically identified specimen of an ichthyosaur, a dolphin-like, ocean-dwelling reptile from the time of the dinosaurs. Two centuries later, less than 50 miles away, an 11-year-old girl named Ruby Reynolds found a fossil from another ichthyosaur. It appears to be the largest marine reptile known to science.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen
title: Israel Signaled That It Would Retaliate Against Iran
description: Also, the House is set to vote on aid for Ukraine and Israel. Here’s the latest at the end of Wednesday.
content: Israel’s prime minister, Benjamin Netanyahu, emerged today from talks with European diplomats resolute that his country would not bow to outside pressure in responding to the recent attack by Iran. Britain’s foreign secretary acknowledged after the meeting that an Israeli reprisal seemed inevitable.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Coy
title: What Would the Economy Look Like Under a Second Biden Term?
description: In all likelihood, it would amount to more of the same. We could do worse.
content: President Biden is campaigning on four more years of yummy stew. A lot of voters are saying, “I like you, but I don’t like your stew.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor
title: Biden Weighs in on Caitlin Clark Salary Debate After W.N.B.A. Draft
description: President Biden’s remarks on the issue came shortly after Caitlin Clark, the University of Iowa basketball star, was selected first in the W.N.B.A. draft.
content: President Biden jumped into a debate about gender and sports this week, calling for pay equity for women athletes after Caitlin Clark, the University of Iowa basketball standout, was selected first in the W.N.B.A. Draft.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Eavis
title: Trains, Trucks and Tractors: The Race to Reroute Goods From Baltimore
description: Since the collapse of the Key Bridge, other East Coast ports have absorbed the cargo previously handled in Baltimore, but some parts of the supply chain like trucking are struggling.
content: New John Deere tractors made their way last week through the sprawling port of Brunswick, Ga., their distinctive green paint glinting in the sunshine. Stevedores drove the tractors up a ramp into the belly of the Leo Spirit, a ship that would take them to Asia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Danny Hakim
title: Prosecutions of Fake Electors for Trump Gain Ground in Swing States
description: Georgia, Michigan and Nevada have already brought charges against people who posed as electors for Donald Trump, and Arizona and Wisconsin have active investigations.
content: The chairman of the Nevada Republican Party has been indicted. So has the former chairman of the Georgia G.O.P. In Michigan, a former co-chairwoman of the state party is facing charges.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Corbin
title: Spot to Park
description: Joseph Gangi makes our eyes play tricks on us.
content: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yan Zhuang
title: Heavy Rain and Floods Kill 19 in Oman and Disrupt Dubai Airport
description: A year’s worth of rain fell in one day in some areas across Oman and the United Arab Emirates, bringing cities to a standstill.
content: Follow our coverage of the flooding in Oman and Dubai.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy Engle
title: Has Your Birth Order Shaped Who You Are?
description: Does it matter if you’re the firstborn, the middle child, the youngest or somewhere in between?
content: Where do you fall in the family birth order? Are you the eldest? The middle child? The youngest? Or are you an only child? Do you think your placement has affected your life and how your family sees and treats you?
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Language of Gender Identity
description: Readers discuss an essay that criticized wording like “sex assigned at birth.” Also: Power over principle; the electric grid; Shakespeare’s insights.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Risen
title: Anne Innis Dagg, Who Studied Giraffes in the Wild, Dies at 91
description: She was believed to be the first Western scientist to study the animals in their natural habitat, but she struggled to overcome sexism in academia.
content: Anne Innis Dagg, who broke ground in the 1950s as one of the world’s first biologists to study giraffes in the wild, then spent decades fighting sexism in Canadian universities before finally finding long-overdue acclaim in the 2010s, died on April 1 in Kitchener, Ontario, west of Toronto. She was 91.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel E. Slotnik
title: Wednesday Briefing
description: Israel’s difficult choices on Iran.
content: Israeli leaders were weighing a set of possible responses to Iran’s airstrike, aimed at achieving different outcomes: deterring a future attack, placating Israel’s U.S. allies and avoiding all-out war.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maya King
title: As Civil Rights Era Fades From Memory, Generation Gap Divides Black Voters
description: Many older Black voters see moral and political reasons to vote. Younger Black voters feel far less motivated to cast a ballot for Democrats or even at all.
content: For years, Loretta Green has voted at her Southwest Atlanta precinct wearing the same custom T-shirt emblazoned with a photo of her first voter registration card, dated to 1960. The front of it reads: “This is why I vote.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David French, Mary McCord and Ken White
title: ‘It’s a Very Winnable Case’: Three Writers Dissect the Trump Trial
description: Debate and analysis about the case, jury selection and anticipation for a potential witness.
content: David French, a Times columnist, hosted a written online conversation with the former federal prosecutors Mary McCord and Ken White to discuss and debate the Trump criminal trial in Manhattan and how, or if, the outcome will matter to voters.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: 2,000 Bags
description: What’s your favorite bag? Can you ever have too many?
content: A glamorous Louis Vuitton, Gucci or Fendi. A stunning thrift store find. Or perhaps your beat-up old school knapsack? Do you have a favorite bag?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Gold
title: Defendant Trump Heads to Harlem to Rail Against Crime, and Alvin Bragg
description: After a day in court, Donald Trump visited a bodega in Harlem where a clerk stabbed a man in 2022 and was charged by Alvin Bragg, who also leveled felony charges against the former president.
content: In his first campaign stop since his criminal trial in Manhattan began, former President Donald J. Trump on Tuesday visited a bodega in Harlem where he made a pointed attack on the district attorney prosecuting him and portrayed himself as tough on crime, a central theme of his 2024 run.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anna Martin, Julia Botero, Christina Djossa, Reva Goldberg, Emily Lang, Davis Land, Jen Poyant, Daniel Ramirez, Dan Powell, Marion Lozano, Diane Wong, Rowan Niemisto and Pat McCusker
title: Why John Magaro of ‘Past Lives’ Could Never Love a Picky Eater
description: For the actor, compatibility comes down to food. You need to be able to share.
content: The actor John Magaro is picky about whom he goes to dinner with. Magaro is an adventurous eater. So whether he’s buying offal from the butcher, making stews from the 1800s or falling in love over a plate of rabbit, he says it’s important to him that the people he shares a meal with are willing to be curious. For Magaro, it’s about more than personal preferences. Sharing a meal and connecting with other people, he says, is the bedrock of society.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Danny Hakim
title: N.R.A. to Overhaul Charity It’s Accused of Using as a ‘Piggy Bank’
description: The gun group settled with the District of Columbia’s attorney general, who said it had misused tax-deductible donations. The N.R.A. denies all wrongdoing in the case.
content: The National Rifle Association reached a settlement on Wednesday with the District of Columbia’s attorney general, agreeing to make governance changes that would curtail its use of millions of dollars raised by an affiliated charity accused of mishandling tax-deductible donations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Livia Albeck-Ripka
title: Deluge Batters U.A.E. and Oman, Killing at Least 20
description: The heavy rains also flooded parts of Dubai International Airport, causing scores of flight delays and cancellations, and brought other cities in the U.A.E. to a standstill.
content: A relentless deluge of rain battered the United Arab Emirates and Oman this week, killing at least 20 people, causing scores of delays and cancellations at Dubai’s airport and bringing other cities to a standstill in what experts have described as a weather system supercharged by climate change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christine Hauser
title: Mount Ruang Erupts in Indonesia, Spewing Lava Thousands of Feet Into the Sky
description: Hundreds of earthquakes were detected in the weeks preceding the eruption of the volcano in North Sulawesi province. Hundreds of people were evacuated.
content: Mount Ruang, a volcano in Indonesia, erupted on Tuesday, spewing fiery lava and ash thousands of feet into the night sky and forcing the evacuation of hundreds of people in the North Sulawesi province, according to the authorities and local news reports.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni
title: Johnson Needs Democrats on Ukraine, Handing Them Power to Shape Aid Plan
description: The Republican speaker’s elaborate strategy for passing a foreign aid package over his party’s objections will require the cooperation of Democrats to push it through — and possibly save his job.
content: Speaker Mike Johnson’s elaborate plan for pushing aid to Ukraine through the House over his own party’s objections relies on an unusual strategy: He is counting on House Democrats and their leader, Representative Hakeem Jeffries of New York, to provide the votes necessary to clear the way for it to come to the floor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vimal Patel
title: How to Define the Term ‘Antisemitism’ Is the Subject of Bitter Debate
description: Several university task forces created in response to student protests over the Israel-Hamas war have struggled to identify what, precisely, constitutes antisemitism.
content: Many donors, politicians and Jewish students have pressured their colleges to confront antisemitism more forcefully.But one challenge can make the whole exercise feel like quicksilver.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Szalai
title: Long Before Trump, Immigrant Detention Was Arbitrary and Cruel
description: “In the Shadow of Liberty,” by the historian Ana Raquel Minian, chronicles America’s often brutal treatment of noncitizens, including locking them up without charge.
content: Completely uncontroversial statements about Donald J. Trump are vanishingly rare these days, but I think I can propose one: Trump isn’t exactly known for his powers of attention. During his four years as president, it was nearly impossible for him to focus on any policy question for very long — something that even his most committed supporters would be hard-pressed to deny.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neal E. Boudette
title: VW Workers in Tennessee Start Vote on U.A.W., Testing Union Ambitions
description: The United Automobile Workers hopes contract gains at the Big Three carmakers will provide momentum in a broad effort to organize nonunion plants.
content: Last fall the United Automobile Workers union won big pay increases from the Detroit automakers, and the impact rippled quickly through the nonunion auto plants scattered across the South.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: Business and a Second Trump Term
description: Times reporters discuss the relationship between major C.E.O.s and Donald Trump.
content: If Donald Trump wins a second term, he has promised to govern as no modern president has, imposing steep tariffs, rounding up immigrants, freeing Jan. 6 rioters and possibly pulling out of NATO. Trump has signaled that he will accomplish all this by appointing loyalists, rather than the more moderate military leaders and corporate executives from his first term.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dana Rubinstein and William K. Rashbaum
title: Top Adviser to Mayor Adams Is Hit With a Second Harassment Lawsuit
description: The aide, Timothy Pearson, was accused of harassing and retaliating against a second police sergeant under his watch.
content: One of Mayor Eric Adams’s closest confidants was sued on Wednesday for the second time in a month over accusations that he harassed and retaliated against a New York Police Department sergeant he oversaw.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Walker Mimms
title: Marian Zazeela, an Artist of Light and Design, Dies at 83
description: She pivoted from painting to lighting exhibitions, performance art, graphic design and minimalist music, performed with her husband, the composer La Monte Young.
content: In avant-garde New York, one of the most pilgrimaged sites has been the “Dream House,” a sensory environment that since 1993 has occupied the third story of a walk-up on Church Street in Lower Manhattan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David McCabe
title: What a TikTok Ban Would Mean for the U.S. Defense of an Open Internet
description: Global digital rights advocates are watching to see if Congress acts, worried that other countries could follow suit with app bans of their own.
content: For decades, the United States has fashioned itself the champion of an open internet, arguing that the web should be largely unregulated and that digital data should flow around the globe unhindered by borders. The government has argued against internet censorship abroad and even funded software that lets people in autocratic states get around online content restrictions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Frank Rojas
title: Bravely Exploring the Squalor of a ‘Boy Room’
description: Male 20-somethings are showing off their messy apartments in a video series that poses the implicit question, “You live like this?”
content: In her new video series, the comedian Rachel Coster explores some of the foulest, most unsightly corners of New York City. No, not the grimy sidewalks of Times Square or the platforms of especially smelly subway stations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Montei
title: Can a Sexless Marriage Be a Happy One?
description: Experts and couples are challenging the conventional wisdom that sex is essential to relationships.
content: Will and Rose met online 10 years ago. His screen name was professorparsley, and he looked the part — tall and thin, with glasses, features that Rose found attractive. On their first date, Rose learned that Will was a college student living with his mother, and his handle came from a nickname given to him by a child at an art camp where he worked. They laugh about it now, as they do with most things. Will thought Rose was exciting and direct. He grew up in suburban Ontario, and she was from Southern California, which was like another world to him. Right away, what they loved about each other were their differences.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gina Kolata
title: Sleep Apnea Reduced in People Who Took Weight-Loss Drug, Eli Lilly Reports
description: The company reported results of clinical trials involving Zepbound, an obesity drug in the same class as Novo Nordisk’s Wegovy.
content: The pharmaceutical manufacturer Eli Lilly announced on Wednesday that its obesity drug tirzepatide, or Zepbound, provided considerable relief to overweight or obese people who had obstructive sleep apnea, or episodes of stopped breathing during sleep.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian Seibert
title: Review: Limbs Hook Onto Limbs as Bodies Endlessly Intertwine
description: The Sydney Dance Company’s “ab [intra]” at the Joyce Theater is impressive but chilly.
content: “Ab[intra],” the title of the work that Sydney Dance Company from Australia is performing at the Joyce Theater this week, is Latin for “from within.” But the Latinate words that the dance brings to mind are the ones that start with “circum,” or ”around.” The work’s most remarkable feature is how the dancers wrap around one another.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert D. McFadden
title: Bob Graham, Former Florida Governor and Senator, Dies at 87
description: After the 9/11 attacks, Mr. Graham became an outspoken critic of President George W. Bush’s response and voted against invading Iraq.
content: Bob Graham, a Florida Democrat who as a little-known state senator cleaned stables and waited on tables in a clever populist strategy that helped to boost him into the governorship, the United States Senate and a run for the presidency, died on Tuesday at his home in Gainesville, Fla. He was 87.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $1.4 Million Homes in North Carolina, Idaho and Connecticut
description: A Tudor Revival cottage in Biltmore Forest, a ranch house and guesthouse in Boise and a 1991 home in Kent.
content: This house is known as the Silversmith Cottage, a reference to the architect and silversmith who designed and once owned it: William Waldo Dodge, who worked extensively in Asheville in the 1920s and 1930s, and was influenced by Arts and Crafts style and the area’s mountainous landscape. It is part of a community of homes — several listed on the National Register of Historic Places — built on land that once belonged to the Biltmore estate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse Wegman and Vishakha Darbha
title: Have Faith in the Trump Trial Jurors
description: Jesse Wegman on why “the system is operating as intended.”
content: Donald Trump’s criminal trial in Manhattan has begun, and while the former president is adamant that it’s a sham, the Times editorial board member Jesse Wegman begs to differ. In this audio essay for “The Opinions,” Wegman argues that Trump’s jury trial is an example of one of the most important features of the American Constitution on display.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ronen Bergman, Farnaz Fassihi, Eric Schmitt, Adam Entous and Richard Pérez-Peña
title: Miscalculation Led to Escalation in Clash Between Israel and Iran
description: Israeli officials say they didn’t see a strike on a high-level Iranian target in Syria as a provocation, and did not give Washington a heads-up about it until right before it happened.
content: Israel was mere moments away from an airstrike on April 1 that killed several senior Iranian commanders at Iran’s embassy complex in Syria when it told the United States what was about to happen.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Applications Open! The New York Times Illustration Portfolio Review
description: We’re inviting illustrators from around the world to share their work with art directors from The New York Times. Apply by June 21, 2024.
content: We will select 80 illustrators to be paired with art directors from The New York Times for individual portfolio critiques. The art directors will offer feedback and guidance to further your work.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Roach
title: Where Do the Gardeners You Admire Turn for Advice? To These Newsletters.
description: A horticulture expert shares his must-read list.
content: As a boy in Tennessee, Jared Barnes learned from his great-grandfather to place his lanky tomato seedlings on their sides when he was transplanting them, so they could root in all along their stems.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Fandos, Stephanie Saul and Sharon Otterman
title: Columbia’s President Tells Congress That Action Is Needed Against Antisemitism
description: Nemat Shafik said some contested phrases — like “from the river to the sea” — might warrant discipline, angering some supporters of academic freedom.
content: The president of Columbia said the university had suspended 15 students. She promised that one visiting professor “will never work at Columbia again.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix
title: Jimmy Kimmel Notes ‘Another Stormy Day’ in ‘The Orange People’s Court’
description: Kimmel said that former president Donald J. Trump is starring “as the defendant in his first of many criminal trials to come.”
content: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Nehamas
title: Biden to Run Ads Across Pennsylvania Attacking Trump on the Economy
description: Winning the state, where he narrowly defeated Donald J. Trump in 2020, is crucial to his re-election strategy.
content: As President Biden tours Pennsylvania, his campaign will run a new ad promoting his commitment to organized labor and attacking the economic policies of former President Donald J. Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Fandos
title: Stefanik Has Taken Aim at Elite College Presidents
description: Representative Elise Stefanik was already a rising star within her party, but her grilling of the presidents of Harvard, Penn and M.I.T. at a December hearing became a defining moment.
content: She may not be a committee chair, but perhaps no single Republican lawmaker has done more to exert pressure on elite universities since the Israel-Gaza war began than Representative Elise Stefanik of New York.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Holly Burns
title: A Little Bit of Dirt Is Good for You
description: Go on, grab a handful of soil or hike a muddy trail: It can benefit everything from your mood to your microbiome.
content: Scientists have long known that a little dirt can be good for you. Research has suggested that people who grow up on farms, for instance, have lower rates of Crohn’s disease, asthma and allergies, likely because of their exposure to a diverse array of microbes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Linda Qiu
title: Fact-Checking Trump’s Defenses in His Court Cases
description: The former president has trotted out a host of false and misleading claims to defend his conduct, attack judges and prosecutors and portray himself as a victim of political persecution.
content: As former President Donald J. Trump battles a series of criminal and civil actions while he runs to reclaim the White House, he has put his legal woes at center stage, making them a rallying cry for his re-election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jodie Ginsberg
title: The Israeli Censorship Regime Is Growing. That Needs to Stop.
description: Barring outside journalists from Gaza and the killings of those covering the war must stop.
content: When Russia invaded Ukraine in 2022, newsrooms across the world scrambled to send their reporters to the front lines. Journalists gave the international public firsthand experience of the conflict. Air raid sirens blared during live on-air reports. Reporters flinched at nearby explosions. They brought the world to the heart of the fighting: “20 Days in Mariupol,” a documentary that showcased an Associated Press report on the attack on the city, won an Oscar last month. That report, among other things, helped debunk Russian claims that the bombing of a maternity hospital, in which three people were killed, was “staged.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Euan Ward, Ronen Bergman and Adam Rasgon
title: Attack by Hezbollah Injures 14 Israeli Soldiers in Border Village
description: The Lebanese militant group said the drone and missile attack was in response to Israeli airstrikes that killed two Hezbollah commanders.
content: The Lebanese militant group Hezbollah claimed responsibility for a cross-border drone and missile attack in northern Israel on Wednesday that the Israeli military said had injured 14 soldiers, six of them severely.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane
title: Alabama Runoff Elections Set Field in Newly Competitive House District
description: Shomari Figures, a Democrat who worked in the Justice Department, and Caroleene Dobson, a Republican newcomer, advanced in the state’s Second Congressional District.
content: Shomari Figures, a Democrat who worked in the Justice Department, will face Caroleene Dobson, a lawyer and Republican political newcomer, this November for the seat in Alabama’s Second Congressional District, according to The Associated Press.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Bleak View of War’s Third Year as Ukraine Strains to Fire Back
description: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, April 17, 2024.
content: “If one side can shoot and the other side can’t shoot back, the side that can’t shoot back loses.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Collins-Hughes
title: In Belfast and Ballybeg, Forging a Bolder Future
description: “Agreement,” at Irish Arts Center, and “Philadelphia, Here I Come!,” at Irish Repertory Theater, have a timeless feel, rooted in their eras and resonant in ours.
content: In more placid times, it would be downright bizarre to classify Owen McCafferty’s political drama “Agreement” as feel-good entertainment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Styles Desk
title: The Ugly State of Shoe Collaborations
description: Blingy Crocs, punk Uggs and spangled sneakers, oh my.
content: Two truths: Fashion has long been enamored by the “ugly shoe.” Balenciaga made chunky dad sneakers; Gucci offered fur-lined loafers; and Schiaparelli introduced anatomical boots that look more like they belong in a surrealism exhibition than on someone’s feet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Supreme Court Backs Police Officer in Job Bias Case
description: The officer, Jatonya Muldrow, said she had been transferred to a less desirable position based on her sex. Lower courts ruled that she had failed to show concrete harm.
content: The Supreme Court unanimously ruled on Wednesday that a female police officer in St. Louis may sue for employment discrimination based on her sex over a forced lateral transfer to another position in the police department.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sean T. Collins
title: ‘Shogun’: Anna Sawai on Her Character’s Final Transformation
description: In an interview, the actor discusses the most recent episode of the FX drama and how her Lady Mariko “wants to fulfill her purpose.”
content: This interview includes spoilers for the ninth episode of “Shogun.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Today’s Wordle Review
description: In case you need some puzzle help.
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Roy
title: Who Doesn’t Want to Be a Traitor?
description: Reality stars and other people with some degree of fame are making no secret of their hopes to join the next cast of the hit show “The Traitors.”
content: The American version of the reality game show “The Traitors,” after the release of its first season on Peacock last year, won an Emmy Award for its casting.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Hirsch
title: F.T.C. Said to Consider Blocking Major Fashion Merger
description: Regulators are expected to meet next week to discuss the $8.5 billion deal between Coach’s owner, Tapestry, and Michael Kors’s parent company, Capri Holdings, which would create a U.S. luxury conglomerate.
content: The Federal Trade Commission is preparing to sue to block a luxury fashion mega merger, Tapestry’s $8.5 billion takeover of Capri Holdings, two people with knowledge of the matter said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater
title: Senate Dismisses Impeachment Charges Against Mayorkas Without a Trial
description: Democrats quickly swept aside the articles of impeachment accusing the homeland security secretary of refusing to enforce immigration laws and breach of public trust, calling them unconstitutional.
content: The Senate on Wednesday dismissed the impeachment case against Alejandro N. Mayorkas, the homeland security secretary, voting along party lines before his trial got underway to sweep aside two charges accusing him of failing to enforce immigration laws and breaching the public trust.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katherine Rosman
title: A New York Conference Focuses on the Crisis of the Uyghurs
description: Elisha Wiesel, son of the writer Elie Wiesel, says the group’s plight has echoes of the Holocaust.
content: Good morning. It’s Wednesday. Today we are speaking with Elisha Wiesel about a two-day conference on the plight of the Uyghurs that is being held in New York.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Nehamas and Jim Tankersley
title: Biden, Competing With Trump to Be Tough on China, Calls for Steel Tariffs
description: Speaking to the United Steelworkers union in Pittsburgh, the president urged major increases to some tariffs on steel and aluminum products from China.
content: President Biden on Wednesday called for major increases to some tariffs on steel and aluminum products from China, speaking to members of a national steelworkers union in Pittsburgh as he vies with former President Donald J. Trump for votes in Northern industrial states.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Sperling
title: A New Home for Sundance? Festival Organizers Say It’s Possible.
description: A 13-year contract with Park City, Utah, is set to expire in 2026 and the film festival is beginning a review process to see if it should move.
content: For the past 40 years, the Sundance Film Festival, the influential annual gathering focused on independent film, has been indelibly linked with the snowy mountain town of Park City, Utah.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Orlando Mayorquín
title: Woman Admits Killing Pregnant Teenager for Her Baby
description: Clarisa Figueroa, 51, of Chicago, pleaded guilty and was sentenced to 50 years in prison. Prosecutors say she strangled the young mother and tried to pass the baby off as her own.
content: A Chicago woman who killed a pregnant teenager and aimed to pass the baby off as her own pleaded guilty to murder Tuesday and was sentenced to 50 years in prison, prosecutors said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Specia
title: A Timeline of Britain’s Troubled Plan to Send Asylum Seekers to Rwanda
description: The U.K. government hoped to pass a bill this week, two years after the plan was first unveiled, in an effort to override a ruling by Britain’s highest court.
content: Britain’s Conservative government hoped to pass the Safety of Rwanda Bill on Wednesday, after a prolonged back and forth through the two houses of Parliament in which the legislation has come under sustained criticism. But the showdown over the bill continued.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Yoon and Hari Kumar
title: Why Does It Take India Six Weeks to Vote?
description: The election is a giant undertaking that requires millions of poll workers, voting machines and security forces to cover deserts, mountains, forests and megacities.
content: When Indians start heading to the polls on Friday, it will be just the beginning of a colossal democratic process. Not until June 4, after six weeks of voting, will India know whether its powerful prime minister, Narendra Modi, will remain in office for a third term.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Cameron
title: Trump Demands a Cut of Donations From Campaigns That Use His Name
description: The Trump campaign said that candidates using his brand should turn over at least 5 percent of donations and encouraged them to send more than the minimum.
content: The presidential campaign of former President Donald J. Trump said in a letter to Republican vendors that candidates may use his name, image and likeness in campaign materials only if they send at least 5 percent of donations that they receive to Mr. Trump’s campaign.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Caron
title: Take This Dance Class and Call Me in the Morning
description: Prescriptions for social activities, exercise and the arts — first popularized in Britain — are coming to America. But some experts say the U.S. health care system may get in the way.
content: Last spring, Tia Washington, 52, a mother of three in Dublin, Calif., received a stern warning from her doctor: If she didn’t quickly gain control of her high blood pressure, she was likely to end up in the emergency room.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aaron Boxerman
title: U.N. Report Describes Physical Abuse and Dire Conditions in Israeli Detention
description: Some Palestinians recounted being beaten with metal bars or the butts of guns, according to the report. Israeli officials have said that the rights of detainees are respected.
content: Gazans released from Israeli detention described graphic scenes of physical abuse in testimonies gathered by United Nations workers, according to a report released on Tuesday by UNRWA, the U.N. agency for Palestinian refugees.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Austen
title: Nine People, Including an Airline Worker, Are Arrested in $14.5 Million Gold Heist
description: The stolen gold was partly used to buy guns that were bound for Canada, the police said.
content: It was a brazen theft: thousands of gold bars and millions of dollars in bank notes stolen a year ago from Toronto’s international airport.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Stevens
title: Tribeca Festival to Feature Brat Pack and Lily Gladstone Films
description: Organizers released the event lineup for the annual New York event, set for June. It includes films that trace the lives of Linda Perry and Avicii.
content: The 2024 Tribeca Festival will offer the world premieres of a Brat Pack documentary, a movie starring Lily Gladstone and films that trace the lives of the music world figures Linda Perry and Avicii, organizers said Wednesday as they announced the event lineup.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Mullin
title: NPR Editor Who Accused Broadcaster of Liberal Bias Resigns
description: Uri Berliner, who has worked at NPR for 25 years, said in an essay last week that the nonprofit had allowed progressive bias to taint its coverage.
content: Uri Berliner, the NPR editor who accused the broadcaster of liberal bias in an online essay last week, prompting criticism from conservatives and recrimination from many of his co-workers, has resigned from the nonprofit.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ronen Bergman, Isabel Kershner, Julian E. Barnes and Russell Goldman
title: Israel ponders a response to Iran’s attack, with each choice a risk.
description: In debating how to respond to last weekend’s Iranian airstrike, Israel’s war cabinet is choosing between options that could deter future attacks or de-escalate hostilities.
content: Israeli leaders on Tuesday were debating how best to respond to Iran’s unprecedented weekend airstrike, officials said, weighing a set of options calibrated to achieve different strategic outcomes: deterring a similar attack in the future, placating their American allies and avoiding all-out war.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse Green
title: Review: In ‘Sally & Tom,’ Plantation Scandal Meets Backstage Farce
description: The 30-year relationship between Sally Hemings and Thomas Jefferson is the basis for Suzan-Lori Parks’s hilarious and harrowing nesting doll of a play.
content: If I were reviewing “The Pursuit of Happiness,” produced by a “low-budget-no-budget” troupe called Good Company, I might note that the subtlety, cleverness and humanity with which it approaches the story of Sally Hemings and Thomas Jefferson come as quite a surprise. After all, Good Company is best known for “politically charged,” “finger-waggy” provocations like “Patriarchy on Parade” and “Listen Up, Whitey, Cause It’s All Your Fault” — work that leaves audiences running for the exits while casts bid them farewell with the bird.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sharon Otterman
title: In Congress, Columbia’s Leaders Try to Please. At Home, They Face Anger.
description: For Columbia’s president, Nemat Shafik, a hearing on antisemitism went relatively well. But on campus, intense protests suggest a difficult road ahead for the university.
content: Representative Elise Stefanik leaned into the microphone and volleyed a series of questions at the university president sitting in front of her. It was about three hours into a congressional hearing examining antisemitism at Columbia University, and the president, Nemat Shafik, paused, sighed and gave a nervous laugh.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gregory Schmidt
title: Inflation in U.K. Slows to 3.2%, Lowest in More Than 2 Years
description: As the economy cools, pressure is building on the Bank of England to cut interest rates.
content: Consumer prices in Britain rose at the slowest rate in two and a half years, the country’s Office for National Statistics reported on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catie Edmondson
title: Johnson Pushes Ahead on Foreign Aid Bill, Teeing Up a Weekend Vote
description: The embattled Republican speaker said he expected Saturday votes on the long-stalled package of aid to Ukraine, Israel and other U.S. allies, as well as fresh sanctions on Iran.
content: Speaker Mike Johnson on Wednesday told Republicans that the House would vote Saturday evening on his foreign aid package for Israel and Ukraine, pushing through resistance in his own party to advance a long-stalled national security spending package for U.S. allies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Tracy
title: Sons of Paul McCartney and John Lennon Release New Song
description: James McCartney teamed with Sean Ono Lennon for “Primrose Hill,” a ballad with echoes of the Beatles aesthetic.
content: For six decades, the partnership summarized by the songwriting credit “Lennon-McCartney” has been pop music’s gold standard. So there was some surprise last week when fans woke up to a brand-new track from McCartney and Lennon — if not the same duo.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carol Rosenberg
title: Guantánamo Bay Opens an Extra Courtroom
description: Planners added the national security courtroom for pretrial hearings and to prepare for the possibility of a Sept. 11 trial.
content: Military staff members have yet to put a clock on a wall or stabilize the air-conditioning. Yet the Pentagon managed to open its long-delayed $4 million secondary courtroom this week and hold simultaneous hearings in adjacent chambers at Guantánamo Bay.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Crowley
title: Blinken Arrives in Italy for Talks on Israel and Ukraine at G7 Meeting
description: The U.S. secretary of state and his counterparts are gathering as world leaders try to contain the fallout from the Israel-Hamas war.
content: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken arrived in Italy on Wednesday for a gathering of foreign ministers from the Group of 7 nations at which the Middle East turmoil and the fate of Ukraine will be central topics.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Schmall
title: Women Talk Through Their Abortions on TikTok
description: At a time of heightened confusion and legal battles over access to abortion, women are looking to social media for answers.
content: “Have an abortion with me,” a single mother from Brooklyn named Sunni says as she twirls around her kitchen to light jazzy piano, before walking TikTok viewers through the steps she took to end her pregnancy at home.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Nicholson
title: Denis Villeneuve Answers All Your Questions About ‘Dune: Part Two’
description: He explains why Lady Jessica’s face is so heavily tattooed, whether Paul considers himself the Messiah and what he thinks of those Javier Bardem memes.
content: This weekend, “Dune: Part Two” muscles back into IMAX theaters with the verve of Timothée Chalamet rodeo-riding a giant sandworm. After nearly two months in theaters, the film is the current champion of this year’s box office race, with a total take of more than $680 million. (It’s also available to rent or buy on some streaming platforms.) The film’s success is thanks in part to audiences that have returned over and over to get lost in the rocky warrens and spiritual reckonings of the planet Arrakis. One admirer reports he’s seen the movie 25 times to date.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Javier C. Hernández
title: Lincoln Center’s Summer Festival to Focus on Civic Bonds
description: The third edition of Summer for the City will feature hip-hop, comedy, classical music and more, under the motto “life, liberty and happiness.”
content: Lincoln Center said on Wednesday that it would devote its summer festival to themes of community and civic participation, with a mix of hip-hop, comedy, dance, classical music and more under the motto “life, liberty and happiness.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Johnny Diaz
title: Atlas, a Humanoid Robot From Boston Dynamics, Is Leaping Into Retirement
description: It has been replaced by a new model, which will be used in automotive manufacturing. A farewell video featured the old machine running outdoors, performing back flips and awkwardly shimmying.
content: Atlas, the humanoid robot that dazzled followers for more than a decade with its outdoor running, awkward dancing and acrobatic back flips, has powered down. In other words, it is retiring.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mitch Smith
title: Michigan Democrats Reclaim Full Control of Statehouse With Special Election Wins
description: The departure of two Democratic representatives who won suburban mayoral posts last fall evenly split the Michigan House.
content: Michigan Democrats started 2023 with full control of state government for the first time since the 1980s. They ended the year in a political bind after two House members left to become mayors of suburbs, leaving that chamber with an even partisan split and making it impossible for Democrats to pass bills without Republican support.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Thursday Briefing: Israel Seems Poised to Retaliate
description: Also, a deadly Russian missile strike in Ukraine and “green Islam” in Indonesia.
content: Top European diplomats traveled to Israel yesterday to make one more plea for the country to show restraint in response to Iran’s aerial attack over the weekend. But David Cameron, Britain’s foreign secretary, said that a reprisal seemed inevitable.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Baker
title: As Lahaina Burned, Fire Crews Waited an Hour for Equipment
description: A new analysis of the August inferno on the island of Maui in Hawaii describes heroic efforts by firefighters. But it also finds many ways the town could have been better prepared.
content: There were warnings of high wildfire danger in the days before a deadly blaze overtook the town of Lahaina in Hawaii last year, but the Maui Fire Department did little to get crews set up in areas at risk, then struggled to launch firefighting vehicles once the blaze began consuming the town, according to an analysis of the wildfire released on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Max Lakin
title: Keith Haring’s Legacy Is Not Found at the Museum
description: Three decades after his death, his work is still sold on products and in stores. But his concept of public art is most powerfully preserved on the street.
content: Toward the end of “Radiant: The Life and Line of Keith Haring,” Brad Gooch’s exhaustive new biography, he quotes from a journal entry Haring made after visiting the Museum of Modern Art in 1988 expressing his “sense of injustice” that contemporaries of his “were represented upstairs in the galleries, while he was confined to the lobby gift shop: ‘They have not even shown one of my pieces yet. In their eyes I don’t exist.’”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Wallace-Wells
title: The New Age of D.I.Y. Medicine
description: A new vaccine for preventing cavities doesn’t have F.D.A. approval or promising clinical trials, but it does have customers.
content: “Cavities are a communicable disease, and if you’re among the 90 percent of Americans who’s ever had one, you probably got them from your mother.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Blinder
title: 4 Takeaways From the Hearing on Antisemitism at Columbia University
description: The closely watched hearing included several tense exchanges between members of Congress and Columbia representatives.
content: Four Columbia University officials, including the university’s president and the leaders of its board, went before Congress on Wednesday to try to extinguish criticism that the campus in New York has become a hub of antisemitic behavior and thought.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patricia Cohen
title: The Global Turn Away From Free-Market Policies Worries Economists
description: More countries are embracing measures meant to encourage their own security and independence, a trend that some say could slow global growth.
